column1: Facebook Pixel and Conversions API
column2: Facebook Pixel and Conversions API

column1: About
column2: About

column1: Facebook Pixel (Client-Side Settings)
column2: Facebook Pixel (Client-Side Settings)

column1: Enabled
column2: Enabled

column1: Enables or disables Facebook Pixel.
column2: Enables or disables Facebook Pixel.

column1: Facebook Pixel ID
column2: Facebook Pixel ID

column1: Your Facebook Pixel ID or comma-separated IDs. WARNING! See the tooltip!
column2: Your Facebook Pixel ID or comma-separated IDs. WARNING! See the tooltip!

column1:
You can use multiple pixels and they will track the same information. There is no limit on the number of IDs. However, Facebook does not recommend using multiple pixels on the same page.
"Using the track function on pages that have multiple pixels initialized (either using multiple base codes or even combining it within one base code) could produce over-firing or unexpected behavior and should be applied only in specific situations."
column2:
You can use multiple pixels and they will track the same information. There is no limit on the number of IDs. However, Facebook does not recommend using multiple pixels on the same page.
"Using the track function on pages that have multiple pixels initialized (either using multiple base codes or even combining it within one base code) could produce over-firing or unexpected behavior and should be applied only in specific situations."

column1: Add Facebook Pixel To
column2: Add Facebook Pixel To

column1: Type page handles (full action names) where you want Facebook Pixel.
column2: Type page handles (full action names) where you want Facebook Pixel.

column1:
The page handles - Synonyms of the page type identifiers. Correspond to "full action names" of controller actions, for example, catalog_product_view
In this option you would type all handles where you want Facebook Pixel to appear.
column2:
The page handles - Synonyms of the page type identifiers. Correspond to "full action names" of controller actions, for example, catalog_product_view
In this option you would type all handles where you want Facebook Pixel to appear.

column1: Enable Facebook Pixel Base Code
column2: Enable Facebook Pixel Base Code

column1: Enable Facebook Pixel base code. WARNING! See the tooltip.
column2: Enable Facebook Pixel base code. WARNING! See the tooltip.

column1: This option enables Facebook Pixel base code. The base code is required for Facebook Pixel to function. If you want to use Facebook Conversions API only, you may disable it.
column2: This option enables Facebook Pixel base code. The base code is required for Facebook Pixel to function. If you want to use Facebook Conversions API only, you may disable it.

column1: Enable noscript Tag
column2: Enable noscript Tag

column1: Enable noscript tag. See the tooltip.
column2: Enable noscript tag. See the tooltip.

column1: This option enables noscript tag. The noscript tag defines an alternate content to be displayed to users that have disabled scripts in their browser or have a browser that does not support scripts. There is no need for noscript tag because Magento requires scripts to function.
column2: This option enables noscript tag. The noscript tag defines an alternate content to be displayed to users that have disabled scripts in their browser or have a browser that does not support scripts. There is no need for noscript tag because Magento requires scripts to function.

column1: Enable AddToCart event on client-side. See the tooltip.
column2: Enable AddToCart event on client-side. See the tooltip.

column1: This option enables the client-side firing of the event. This is done with JavaScript in your visitor/customer web browser by the Facebook Pixel.
column2: This option enables the client-side firing of the event. This is done with JavaScript in your visitor/customer web browser by the Facebook Pixel.

column2: This option will fire PageView event with all other events: CompleteRegistration, InitiateCheckout, Purchase, Search, and ViewContent.

column1: Move Parameters Outside Contents
column2: Move Parameters Outside Contents

column1: Move disallowed parameters outside contents. WARNING! See the tooltip!
column2: Move disallowed parameters outside contents. WARNING! See the tooltip!

column1: This option should be set to "Yes". Facebook Conversions API does not allow any other parameter inside contents except for id, quantity, and item_price. If the contents have only one element this option will try to move disallowed parameters outside contents. If the contents have more than one element then disallowed parameters will be removed from the contents.
column2: This option should be set to "Yes". Facebook Conversions API does not allow any other parameter inside contents except for id, quantity, and item_price. If the contents have only one element this option will try to move disallowed parameters outside contents. If the contents have more than one element then disallowed parameters will be removed from the contents.

column1: Detect Selected SKU
column2: Detect Selected SKU

column1: Try to detect selected SKU for downloadable, simple, virtual, etc. WARNING! See the tooltip!
column2: Try to detect selected SKU for downloadable, simple, virtual, etc. WARNING! See the tooltip!

column1: This feature is heavily dependent on the theme you are using and its customization. It is impossible to predict all possible themes and customizations. Because of this detection will not work on every theme. This is why extension default configuration comes with this feature turned off. You can turn it on, try it out if it is working for you and if it does leave it on, otherwise turn it off. If you are a developer you will be pleased to know that everything is conveniently located in code.phtml file. To make it work, in some cases only the adjustment of few jQuery selectors is needed in others complete rewrite of detection code is needed. Because of this, we do not give any warranty for the detection feature, nor it is covered by our support service.
column2: This feature is heavily dependent on the theme you are using and its customization. It is impossible to predict all possible themes and customizations. Because of this detection will not work on every theme. This is why extension default configuration comes with this feature turned off. You can turn it on, try it out if it is working for you and if it does leave it on, otherwise turn it off. If you are a developer you will be pleased to know that everything is conveniently located in code.phtml file. To make it work, in some cases only the adjustment of few jQuery selectors is needed in others complete rewrite of detection code is needed. Because of this, we do not give any warranty for the detection feature, nor it is covered by our support service.

column1: Enables or disables Facebook Conversions API. WARNING! See the tooltip!
column2: Enables or disables Facebook Conversions API. WARNING! See the tooltip!

column1: Facebook Conversions API will not work without valid Access Token and API Version.
column2: Facebook Conversions API will not work without valid Access Token and API Version.

column1: Facebook Access Token
column2: Facebook Access Token

column1: Your Facebook Access Token. WARNING! See the tooltip!
column2: Your Facebook Access Token. WARNING! See the tooltip!

column1: Facebook Conversions API will not work without a valid Access Token.
column2: Facebook Conversions API will not work without a valid Access Token.

column1: Facebook API Version
column2: Facebook API Version

column1: Your Facebook API Version. WARNING! See the tooltip!
column2: Your Facebook API Version. WARNING! See the tooltip!

column1: Facebook Conversions API will not work without a valid API Version.
column2: Facebook Conversions API will not work without a valid API Version.

column1: Test Event Code
column2: Test Event Code

column1: Your test_event_code for testing events. WARNING! See the tooltip!
column2: Your test_event_code for testing events. WARNING! See the tooltip!

column1: WARNING! Leave this field empty! Only use it for testing purposes. Facebook Conversions API allows you to test your events. Be aware Facebook gives priority to Facebook Pixel (client-side) events. If both Facebook Pixel (client-side) and Facebook Conversions API (server-side) events are fired the latter will be disregarded (dropped). The test_event_code is useful if your Magento store is in production and you want to test server-side events without turning off Facebook Pixel (client-side) events. You can see test events in your Facebook Business Manager.
column2: WARNING! Leave this field empty! Only use it for testing purposes. Facebook Conversions API allows you to test your events. Be aware Facebook gives priority to Facebook Pixel (client-side) events. If both Facebook Pixel (client-side) and Facebook Conversions API (server-side) events are fired the latter will be disregarded (dropped). The test_event_code is useful if your Magento store is in production and you want to test server-side events without turning off Facebook Pixel (client-side) events. You can see test events in your Facebook Business Manager.

column1: Log Events
column2: Log Events

column1: Enable logging of events. WARNING! See the tooltip.
column2: Enable logging of events. WARNING! See the tooltip.

column1: WARNING! Leave this option disabled! Only enable it for debugging purposes.
column2: WARNING! Leave this option disabled! Only enable it for debugging purposes.

column1: Event Firing Mode
column2: Event Firing Mode

column1: Select event firing mode. WARNING! See the tooltip.
column2: Select event firing mode. WARNING! See the tooltip.

column1:
Mode 1
Events fire via AJAX calls. In this mode, you can fire both the Facebook Pixel event and Facebook Conversions API event simultaneously.
Mode 2 (API Only)
Events fire from the server without going to the web browser. In this mode, you cannot send both Facebook Pixel and Facebook Conversions API events simultaneously. If a particular Facebook Conversions API event is enabled, the corresponding Facebook Pixel event is automatically disabled to avoid duplication.
column2:
Mode 1
Events fire via AJAX calls. In this mode, you can fire both the Facebook Pixel event and Facebook Conversions API event simultaneously.
Mode 2 (API Only)
Events fire from the server without going to the web browser. In this mode, you cannot send both Facebook Pixel and Facebook Conversions API events simultaneously. If a particular Facebook Conversions API event is enabled, the corresponding Facebook Pixel event is automatically disabled to avoid duplication.

If the contents have more than one element then disallowed parameters will be removed from the contents.

column1: Category (Category Page)
column2: Category (Category Page)

column1: Add Category-Related Code To
column2: Add Category-Related Code To

column1: Type page handles (full action names) where you want category-related code. See the tooltip.
column2: Type page handles (full action names) where you want category-related code. See the tooltip.

column1:
The page handles - Synonyms of the page type identifiers. Correspond to "full action names" of controller actions, for example, catalog_category_view
In this option you would type all handles where you want to add category-related code.
This option only works for category page handles where category object is set.
column2:
The page handles - Synonyms of the page type identifiers. Correspond to "full action names" of controller actions, for example, catalog_category_view
In this option you would type all handles where you want to add category-related code.
This option only works for category page handles where category object is set.

column1: Event Name
column2: Event Name

column1: Type event name you want to use for category tracking. See the tooltip.
column2: Type event name you want to use for category tracking. See the tooltip.

column1: The proper event should be ViewCategory but Facebook specification does not have this (yet) as standard event. You can use ViewContent. Leave this option to empty if you want only PageView event on category pages. Recommendation is to set this option to empty or use ViewCategory as custom event.
column2: The proper event should be ViewCategory but Facebook specification does not have this (yet) as standard event. You can use ViewContent. Leave this option to empty if you want only PageView event on category pages. Recommendation is to set this option to empty or use ViewCategory as custom event.

column1: Category Parameters to Attributes Mapping
column2: Category Parameters to Attributes Mapping

column1: If you want to add custom parameters to categories. Please see the tooltip.
column2: If you want to add custom parameters to categories. Please see the tooltip.

column1:
Example: gpc=gpc|color=color
As you can see the format is simple
param1=attribute1|param2=attribute2
Facebook Pixel parameter and Magento category attribute are connected by = sign and pairs are separated by | sign.
column2:
Example: gpc=gpc|color=color
As you can see the format is simple
param1=attribute1|param2=attribute2
Facebook Pixel parameter and Magento category attribute are connected by = sign and pairs are separated by | sign.

column2: Product (Product Page - AddToCart, AddToWishlist, ViewContent Events)

column2: Add Product-Related Code To

column1: Type page handles (full action names) where you want product-related code. See the tooltip.
column2: Type page handles (full action names) where you want product-related code. See the tooltip.

column1:
The page handles - Synonyms of the page type identifiers. Correspond to "full action names" of controller actions, for example, catalog_product_view
In this option you would type all handles where you want to add product-related code.
This option only works for product page handles where product object is set.
column2:
The page handles - Synonyms of the page type identifiers. Correspond to "full action names" of controller actions, for example, catalog_product_view
In this option you would type all handles where you want to add product-related code.
This option only works for product page handles where product object is set.

column1: For Bundle Products Use
column2: For Bundle Products Use

column1: Select SKU you want to use for bundle products. See the tooltip.
column2: Select SKU you want to use for bundle products. See the tooltip.

column1:
Examples with contents:

Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Children SKUs
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', quantity: 1}
]

Children SKUs and Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Examples with content_ids:

Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP']

Children SKUs
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL']

Children SKUs and Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL'],
item_group_id: 'SHBP'
column2:
Examples with contents:

Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Children SKUs
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', quantity: 1}
]

Children SKUs and Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Examples with content_ids:

Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP']

Children SKUs
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL']

Children SKUs and Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL'],
item_group_id: 'SHBP'

column1: Use product_group Instead of product (Bundle)
column2: Use product_group Instead of product (Bundle)

column1: For content_type use product_group instead of product. WARNING! See the tooltip!
column2: For content_type use product_group instead of product. WARNING! See the tooltip!

column1:
This option shoud be set to "No".
There is only one scenario when this option should be set to "Yes". That is when you select Product SKU for option For Bundle Products Use. Regarding content_type read this from Facebook documentation: "If the IDs being passed in content_ids or contents parameter are IDs of products then the value should be product. If product group IDs are being passed, then the value should be product_group."
column2:
This option shoud be set to "No".
There is only one scenario when this option should be set to "Yes". That is when you select Product SKU for option For Bundle Products Use. Regarding content_type read this from Facebook documentation: "If the IDs being passed in content_ids or contents parameter are IDs of products then the value should be product. If product group IDs are being passed, then the value should be product_group."

column1: For Grouped Products Use
column2: For Grouped Products Use

column1: Select SKU you want to use for grouped products. See the tooltip.
column2: Select SKU you want to use for grouped products. See the tooltip.

column1:
Examples with contents:

Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Children SKUs
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', quantity: 1}
]

Children SKUs and Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Examples with content_ids:

Product SKU

Children SKUs

Children SKUs and Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL'],
item_group_id: 'SHBP'

The Product SKU option is not recommended because of the nature of grouped products in Magento. From Magento documentation: "Although they are presented as a group, each product in the group is purchased as a separate item. In the shopping cart, each item and the quantity purchased appears as a separate line item."
column2:
Examples with contents:

Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Children SKUs
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', quantity: 1}
]

Children SKUs and Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Examples with content_ids:

Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP']

Children SKUs
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL']

Children SKUs and Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL'],
item_group_id: 'SHBP'

The Product SKU option is not recommended because of the nature of grouped products in Magento. From Magento documentation: "Although they are presented as a group, each product in the group is purchased as a separate item. In the shopping cart, each item and the quantity purchased appears as a separate line item."

Regarding content_type read this from Facebook documentation: "If the IDs being passed in content_ids or contents parameter are IDs of products then the value should be product. If product group IDs are being passed, then the value should be product_group."

There is only one scenario when this option should be set to "Yes". That is when you select Product SKU for option For Grouped Products Use. column1: Select SKU you want to use for simple products. See the tooltip.
column2: Select SKU you want to use for simple products. See the tooltip.

column1: For Virtual Products Use
column2: For Virtual Products Use

column1: Select SKU you want to use for virtual products. See the tooltip.
column2: Select SKU you want to use for virtual products. See the tooltip.

column1: Use content_ids instead of contents
column2: Use content_ids instead of contents

column1: Use content_ids instead of contents for ViewContent event. See the tooltip.
column2: Use content_ids instead of contents for ViewContent event. See the tooltip.

column1: It is recommended to set this option to "No". The contents parameter is required for AddToCart and Purchase events. The ViewContent event can use contents or content_ids parameter. It is better to use contents but you can use content_ids if you want.
column2: It is recommended to set this option to "No". The contents parameter is required for AddToCart and Purchase events. The ViewContent event can use contents or content_ids parameter. It is better to use contents but you can use content_ids if you want.

column1: For Global content_name Use
column2: For Global content_name Use

column1: Type Magento product attribute code you want to use for product global content_name field.
column2: Type Magento product attribute code you want to use for product global content_name field.

column1:
Example: name
Make sure all of your products have this attribute and all of your products have non-empty value for this attribute.
This option is for setting content_name outside contents. If you want to set content_name inside contents per each item then use Product Parameters to Attributes Mapping option and set this option to empty.
column2:
Example: name
Make sure all of your products have this attribute and all of your products have non-empty value for this attribute.
This option is for setting content_name outside contents. If you want to set content_name inside contents per each item then use Product Parameters to Attributes Mapping option and set this option to empty.

column1: For Global content_category Use
column2: For Global content_category Use

column1: Type Magento product attribute code you want to use for product global content_category field.
column2: Type Magento product attribute code you want to use for product global content_category field.

column1:

Make sure all of your products have this attribute and all of your products have non-empty value for this attribute.

column1: Product Parameters to Attributes Mapping
column2: Product Parameters to Attributes Mapping

column1: If you want to add custom parameters to products. WARNING! Please see the tooltip.
column2: If you want to add custom parameters to products. WARNING! Please see the tooltip.

column1:
This option depends on Move Parameters Outside Contents option. If this option is enabled the parameters will be moved outside contents or removed if contents have more than one item.
Example: gpc=gpc|color=color
As you can see the format is simple
param1=attribute1|param2=attribute2
Facebook Pixel parameter and Magento product attribute are connected by = sign and pairs are separated by | sign.
column2:
This option depends on Move Parameters Outside Contents option. If this option is enabled the parameters will be moved outside contents or removed if contents have more than one item.
Example: gpc=gpc|color=color
As you can see the format is simple
param1=attribute1|param2=attribute2
Facebook Pixel parameter and Magento product attribute are connected by = sign and pairs are separated by | sign.

column1: Quote (Checkout Page - InitiateCheckout Event)
column2: Quote (Checkout Page - InitiateCheckout Event)

column1: Add Quote-Related Code To
column2: Add Quote-Related Code To

column1: Type page handles (full action names) where you want quote-related code. See the tooltip.
column2: Type page handles (full action names) where you want quote-related code. See the tooltip.

column1:
The page handles - Synonyms of the page type identifiers. Correspond to "full action names" of controller actions, for example, checkout_index_index
In this option you would type all handles where you want to add quote-related code.
This option only works for checkout page handles where quote object is set.
column2:
The page handles - Synonyms of the page type identifiers. Correspond to "full action names" of controller actions, for example, checkout_index_index
In this option you would type all handles where you want to add quote-related code.
This option only works for checkout page handles where quote object is set.

column1:
Examples with contents:

Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Child SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', quantity: 1}
]

Child SKU and Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Examples with content_ids:

Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP']

Child SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP-7-BL']

Child SKU and Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP-7-BL'],
item_group_id: 'SHBP'
column2:
Examples with contents:

Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Child SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', quantity: 1}
]

Child SKU and Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Examples with content_ids:

Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP']

Child SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP-7-BL']

Child SKU and Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP-7-BL'],
item_group_id: 'SHBP'

column1:
Examples with contents:

Children SKUs
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', quantity: 1}
]

Children SKUs and Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Examples with content_ids:

Children SKUs
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL']

Children SKUs and Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL'],
item_group_id: 'SHBP'

There is no option for Product SKU and that is intentional. From Magento documentation: "Although they are presented as a group, each product in the group is purchased as a separate item. In the shopping cart, each item and the quantity purchased appears as a separate line item."
column2:
Examples with contents:

Children SKUs
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', quantity: 1}
]

Children SKUs and Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Examples with content_ids:

Children SKUs
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL']

Children SKUs and Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL'],
item_group_id: 'SHBP'

There is no option for Product SKU and that is intentional. From Magento documentation: "Although they are presented as a group, each product in the group is purchased as a separate item. In the shopping cart, each item and the quantity purchased appears as a separate line item."

column2: Type parameter name for which you want to use Magento quote ID. Example: quote_id

column1:
Magento quote ID is internal database table auto increment ID.
Example: 3275

If you do not want to use parameter for Magento quote ID leave this field empty.
column2:
